267107574ADC48D0B3F68F751F8A842E.description: View and/or read plays created by Indigenous artists.

B81F1A69C84347CBBD12BCF166431C7F.description: Research Saskatchewan Métis, First Nations and Inuit theatre artists and their work.

321BA3C4E01B4715BBDDED823E393FE7.description: Use various sources of inspiration (e.g., image, sound, story) and research to explore reconciliation-related issues (e.g., racism, healing, treaty negotiations, privilege, relationship building, language loss and revitalization) through dramatic work (e.g., treaty education outcome TR11, indicator -- apply the principles of Canadian treaty making as a means for resolving conflict and represent in drama work).

E5CA2AA90033444395FEADDADE6019FE.description: Engage, where possible, with an Elder, Knowledge Keeper or community leader to listen to experiences or stories and use as inspiration for a creative response involving own drama work.

9C3F0FECE2094691AA32873E7C7C627E.description: Explore how Indigenous perspectives and ways of knowing, including local cultural knowledge, impact the creation of dramatic work.

CC3914EDBDD640A08473E166A6BE9F8F.description: Consider the ways that Saskatchewan theatre productions (e.g., Paper Wheat, Operation Big Rock Story of Mistaseni by SUM Theatre, The Weyburn Project) represent a time and place.

B8A820E49F91491998C3ED782B1934D1.description: Identify, examine, and practically explore the ways that diverse theatre styles have influenced society from the past and in the present.

1FE1AC49EB6F42C28F2D8CF0C7BF1491.description: Analyze the various social, cultural and environmental conditions that inform the creation of dramatic work.

9192581AFDFB4D0291B17C97B49B09F6.description: Recognize the various ways that dramatic works arise from and respond to contemporary issues within society (e.g., gender-based or racially-motivated violence, causes and effects of climate change, impacts of economic disparity, youth mental health).

B6B051A02E544ADA982B221DD1E6EAD3.description: Examine the influence of social, cultural, environmental and personal contexts on drama.

863898A0AF1C43F5A326B3DA1A7E6B1F.description: Present work inspired by a theatre era or tradition (e.g., perform scenes from different eras, present design elements).

80E3C54906C340F5B2208B6D5F6B7A58.description: Provide examples of how theatre traditions continue to evolve.

72B8193A1A504796AC1B1255C1DD34CC.description: Examine theatre traditions representing various cultures and worldviews and explain how they are specific to place and time (e.g., Indigenous storytelling, Greek Theatre, Karagozi shadow puppetry, Talchum mask dance, Kathakali, Theatre of the Oppressed, mummers in Newfoundland).

587997EA267248C09223666C3DF6937D.description: Recognize that artistic practices may be specific to a treaty territory, cultural and/or language group in Saskatchewan and Canada

250AD6A5931B41C8921994B2E7443902.description: Discuss connections between Indigenous artistic traditions (e.g., song, dance, stories) and the land, identity and worldview.

5ADA5A923B9A4E909CC958B714E5F8C3.description: Examine, and explore in own work, one or more theatre traditions.

552CE7C60049440A8C863288812DCE56.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) Goal: Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts, and understand the connection between the arts and the human experience.

6B44CE1CBC43466D81E199848E98AFC1.description: Create a presentation to represent own skills and experiences in theatre and/or film (e.g., portfolio, CV, artist statement, cover letter, audition piece, pitch for a show).

8A8F5C7BB165464EBA6F8DD639638566.description: Volunteer or job shadow, where possible, in a professional or community theatre, theatre school or film production company.

331B38A9C6D343F6979D2E5CCEE386EF.description: Improvise a variety of realistic and absurd scenarios related to working in theatre and/ or film (e.g., terrible auditions, “what not to do” scenarios, inequitable power relationships, interviews, rehearsal conflicts, technical malfunctions, securing an agent or position backstage).

7B3D109FBF784C05A80B04DF3763C9FC.description: Research (e.g., in person, written or recorded interview) a theatre and/or film artist about the “real life” concerns of a working artist (e.g., pay, contracts, hours, health, professional unions and safety).

7DD9052F6B5A427D8BA46686AFCC22F3.description: Research the specifics of working in theatre and/or film, including performance and career opportunities in Saskatchewan.

34CD65B99A46462ABD368CFD43B0C4D5.description: Present a scene which involves audience participation.

2CA5BE76B2F74D058B4A6A66B0CD6B7C.description: Present a scene with an intended impact and gather audience feedback to determine actual impact.

7C74167EA3AF4399930B57F7F7C428F0.description: Research and experiment with the various roles of audience members in participatory theatre (e.g., Boal’s spect-actor, experimental theatre, immersive theatre, improvisational theatre).

672324E1D43743789E2E19C58278179E.description: Critically evaluate various theatrical elements in response to viewing live theatre (e.g., acting, blocking, directorial choices, set, lighting, costumes).

037A62840F584135B7764F00206E898E.description: Observe protocol when attending and viewing live theatre (i.e., live theatre viewed online or through attending live theatre).

C1415ED2783F48639E94365D8F0E896D.description: Discuss the purposes of theatre (e.g., to entertain, to educate, to raise awareness, to initiate change) and how this affects artistic decisions and audience response.

5B04D1379A2146F59A38F597797EF9A0.description: View and reflect on a live or recorded performance and discuss the role of the audience in various types of performances (e.g., conventional Western theatre, children’s theatre, forum theatre, site specific theatre).

D128AA1163C84D689B37F2F417AB7C26.description: Respond critically, using appropriate theatrical language, to live performances (e.g., student work, professional or community theatre).

241E765EB5DD43ADA829C73D288699B2.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and international artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

23BB0452752F4EB6A300F4030EBAC1E8.description: Assess the strengths of the performance and reflect on the collaborative approaches, challenges, and individual contributions encountered in the creative process.

42880662F4884B7380CF594BA72D5012.description: Apply safety procedures and demonstrate proper use of tools, technologies and materials.

09733379361D4EAAB24DD2062AAF1ABD.description: Select a theatre role (e.g., actor, theatre technician, writer, director, designer, stage manager, choreographer, musical director) and demonstrate how technical and artistic choices work together through a sustained performance.

02363E889FAC4B6792758D7777CA84B8.description: Practically explore the designer’s toolbox (e.g., visual skills, use of maquettes, represent mood, use of symbol/metaphor, light, colour, sound) for aesthetic purpose.

FB95D1EB93054BAF86DFFBB2C34941CB.description: Practically explore the actor’s toolbox (e.g., voice, movement, theatrical performance styles, understanding character, awareness of self and space, text notation and memorization).

9D54E54CB29441E79D8258C5E66B7E08.description: Use the language of theatre effectively in performance (e.g., stage directions, lighting cues, blocking).

2053222C39FA439990CBBB310552E84B.description: Present and sustain a performance for an audience (e.g., peers, invited guests, public) that considers the combination of artistic and technical components.

4BE05B47A94045FBA3895B7D48AEE2D7.description: Follow through with the rehearsal process according to the needs of the production.

C5155E46A65443B2A0E36B74D232610C.description: Create a production plan, assign roles, develop a budget and a timeline.

DE20AF081E694A44BBE4CFADB4A132F1.description: Discuss a range of ways of rehearsing (e.g., improvisation, character exploration, linear vs. non-linear, reading, silent, tableau, speed through, technical, blocking, choreography, vocal work, costume parade).

6963474AD7E54F7B9562D6C4108C0BFA.description: Analyze the work using processes such as: researching and analyzing context; reading for meaning and subtext; exploring the ‘given circumstances’; analyzing dialogue and dramatic action and, understanding character through text, motivation, dialogue, physicality.

C5011CD7115046FBA254D6551E8AE3BA.description: Determine criteria for selecting work (e.g. cultural and community considerations, number of people, interest, skills, time, content, budget including production costs including financial implications, theme, style, genre, space, technical requirements, audience).

9B5D3A28CD2047EA984A205966E1890D.description: Investigate a creative process for building a play.

0E96DF5D0CF74D979802A33EB773B658.description: Write and perform in role, representing the voice and diverse perspectives of an individual from a community that is not one’s own (e.g., refugee, corporate leader, single mother, authoritarian leader, dragonslayer, environmental activist, homeless elderly veteran, lost time traveller).

4CD63477BD82419883C090CAF4631717.description: Research examples of appropriation, and discuss ways to respectfully portray the voice and perspective of the “other” in drama and theatre.

7330933A18A24566A9AEAACC07FFD082.description: Discuss issues of appropriation of culture, ideas and voice and its connection to respect, integrity, intellectual property and the representation of own and others’ work in drama and theatre.

D71887AD365947E183D97693DFA32856.description: Examine how the “other” has been represented within traditional (e.g., monologues, one act plays, musicals) and non-traditional (e.g., absurd, clown, performance art) Western and/or non-Western theatre.

C9E176BFEEC4495B999210FB3A0F1817.description: Investigate how diverse voices and perspectives are portrayed in theatre.

1EF37D23A07F464BA1FE9DF465E002FF.description: Investigate artistic voice and perspectives of the “other” (e.g., marginalized individuals and communities, silenced people in history, powerful figures, celebrities, extraterrestrials, fictional characters) through works of dramatic art.

0CC34082B3C24221A2ADA7447A3A19B7.description: Reflect on the successes and challenges encountered during the creative process and/or performance, including self-assessment of own contributions.

24CDE641BF9448138684DF108ABA7611.description: Discuss ways a selected genre, style and/or performance practice has been applied in own work.

645A7C72E7B042A380CBDB54B0DD1A91.description: Experiment with a range of styles, genres and performance practices and use in own work.

837829BE77884589972BD53D662918D7.description: Research, identify and apply conventions from various styles (e.g., dance, speech, magic show, spoken word, clowning, puppet work) of dramatic arts.

6934489AB162406A93BC0919DA17DF55.description: Demonstrate and use a variety of genres, styles and performance practices.

65A9383B4B574646ADB8BB71583828E4.description: Provide constructive feedback on peers’ stories and support each other by identifying and practising ways to refine techniques.

E01995A977D241DF9AEA7318B9BC3C86.description: Tell a story using dramatic techniques (e.g., humour, personal connections, emotion, tension, delivery, pauses) to make a connection with an audience

4123292162544B34B1EDA05328E4B63F.description: Investigate how storytelling (e.g., oral stories, online storytelling sites such as StoryCorps or The Moth Stories, stand-up comedy) and interviews can lead to development of own work and performance.

76F1759DFE4247E0BDB2AC4F94BE05EB.description: Listen to storytellers (e.g., Elders, Knowledge Keepers, artists, parents, grandparents, other teachers, veterans, community members, peers) and discuss the art of storytelling and potential connections to own drama work.

A73BA7F420D34D099FF9C30564562C41.description: Use storytelling in own dramatic work

A0A46AC315AB41DDB9BB05F69594B367.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
